slides.text: Create the poster: 'Your Greatest Discoveries poster should include: your top 5 scientific facts, your favorite experiment, one concept you can explain brilliantly, and one question you still want to answer. Make it colorful and scientific!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the fun part – making your "Greatest Discoveries" poster! You'll pick your top 5 science facts, draw your favorite experiment and tell us why you loved it, explain one science idea that you can teach anyone, and even add a question you're still super curious about. Let's make it look as colorful and exciting as science itself!

slides.text: Prepare your presentation: 'Introduce yourself as a scientist. Share your most amazing discovery. Then DEMONSTRATE one scientific concept — show your audience something real. You are not just telling — you are showing science in action.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to be a scientist on stage! You'll introduce yourself like a brilliant scientist, share your most mind-blowing discovery, and then *show* everyone a science concept in action. It's not just talking about science, it's doing science right in front of them!

slides.text: Present and celebrate: 'Deliver your scientist spotlight presentation with confidence. Then receive your Young Scientist certificate — you have earned it through a year of observation, experimentation, and discovery!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is when you get to shine! You'll give your super cool scientist presentation, and then you'll receive your very own "Young Scientist" certificate. You've worked so hard all year with exploring, testing, and figuring things out, and this certificate shows just how awesome you are!

slides.prompt: Create your Greatest Discoveries poster with top 5 facts, favorite experiment, a concept you can explain, and a question for further investigation. Prepare and deliver a 2-minute scientist spotlight presentation including a live demonstration. Write one summer science investigation goal.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you're going to create your "Greatest Discoveries" poster with your top facts, favorite experiment, a concept you can explain, and a new question to explore. Then, you'll practice your 2-minute scientist spotlight presentation, which includes a live science trick, and finally, you'll even think of a science goal for the summer!

slides.text: Award the certificate: 'On behalf of the scientific community, I am honored to present this Young Scientist certificate to you. You have observed carefully, experimented bravely, asked brilliant questions, and discovered amazing things. Science is not just a subject — it is a way of seeing the world. Keep your scientist eyes open all summer long!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify and articulate key scientific learnings from the year, demonstrate a scientific concept to an audience, present with clarity and confidence, and set meaningful goals for continued scientific inquiry?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the best part – getting your special "Young Scientist" certificate! It means you've been a super observer, a brave experimenter, a curious question-asker, and a fantastic discoverer. Remember to keep your scientist eyes open all summer long, because there are always amazing things to learn!

parent_notes: The science celebration builds scientific identity — the child sees themselves as a scientist, not just someone who studies science. This identity is one of the strongest predictors of future engagement with STEM fields. The certificate is a small gesture with enormous impact: it validates a year of work and declares the child's achievement officially. Make the certificate presentation special — announce it formally, shake hands, and express genuine pride. The summer science goal ensures continuity: a child who investigates a question over the summer maintains scientific thinking habits. Great summer science activities include nature observation, kitchen chemistry, garden experiments, weather tracking, and citizen science projects. The key message: science happens everywhere, not just in a classroom.

title: End-of-Year Art Show and Recorder Concert
description: Students host their art show and perform their recorder concert for family and friends. They guide visitors through their art gallery, perform their musical program, and experience the culmination of a year of creative development in a celebratory event.
instructions:
1. 'Today is the BIG EVENT! Your art show opens and your concert begins!'
2. Final art show setup: hang or display all matted artwork with labels.
3. Welcome guests to the art show:
   - Guide them through the gallery
   - Explain each piece using the artist statements
   - Answer questions about technique and inspiration
4. Transition to the concert:
   - Hand out concert programs
   - Stand in performance position
   - Announce the first piece
5. Perform all concert pieces with confidence and expression.
6. Take a bow after the final piece.
7. Invite guests to browse the art show again after the concert.
8. Receive congratulations and celebrate the achievement.
9. Take photos of the art show and concert.

slides.heading: Art Show and Concert Night
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide tells us that today is a super special day – it's your art show and concert night where you get to show everyone all the amazing things you've made and learned! It's like your own personal party to celebrate how much your creativity has grown this whole year.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the art gallery display and performance area. Arrange audience seating. Have concert programs ready to distribute. Set out a guest book and optional refreshments. Test the performance space for good acoustics.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows all the cool things you'll need for our big event, like your beautiful artwork ready to be shown, your recorder and music, and some special programs for your guests. We also need a place for everyone to sit for the concert, and maybe even some yummy snacks and a book for people to write nice things in. You'll need to find a grown-up to help you get all these things ready!

slides.text: Final preparations: 'Check everything one last time. Is the artwork displayed beautifully? Are the labels attached? Is your recorder ready? Are the concert programs printed? Deep breath — you are ready for your big event!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this is the very last check before everyone arrives! Make sure all your artwork looks perfect on the walls or tables, that the little signs telling people about each piece are there, and that your recorder is ready to play. Take a big, deep breath – you've worked so hard, and you are totally ready for this amazing night!

slides.text: Art show tour: 'Welcome your guests at the entrance. Guide them through your gallery, starting with your earliest piece and ending with your most recent. Read the artist statements and share stories about your creative process.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to be a super friendly host! When your guests arrive, you'll greet them with a big smile and then take them on a tour of your art gallery. You'll show them your art from the beginning of the year all the way to the newest pieces, and tell them all about what inspired you and how you made each one, just like a real art expert!

slides.text: Concert performance: 'When it is time for the concert, invite your audience to sit. Stand tall, take a breath, and announce your first piece. Play each song with the expression and technique you have practiced. Pause between pieces.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for the music part! When it's time for the concert, you'll ask everyone to find a comfy seat, then stand up tall and proud. You'll tell everyone the name of the first song, and then play all your songs with all the practice and feeling you've put in, remembering to take a little pause between each one.

slides.text: Celebrate: 'After the final piece, take a deep bow. You have just hosted an art exhibition AND a concert! Invite your guests to browse the art one more time, sign the guest book, and celebrate together.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! After you play your very last note, you'll take a big, fancy bow because you just hosted both an art show and a concert – that's incredible! Then, you can invite everyone to look at the art again, maybe write something nice in the guest book, and just enjoy celebrating your awesome talent.

slides.prompt: Host the complete art show and concert event. Give art gallery tours with explanations. Perform your full recorder concert program. Take a bow. Invite guests to sign the guest book. Celebrate your year of creative achievement!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the main event where you get to be the star! You'll lead your visitors through the art show, explaining everything about your amazing creations, and then you'll play your recorder concert beautifully for everyone. After the music, you'll take a bow and let your guests sign the guest book to remember this special night.

slides.text: Reflect on the experience: 'You created art, learned music, and shared it all with the people you love. This took courage, creativity, and dedication. Whether you become a professional artist, a weekend painter, or someone who simply appreciates beauty — the creative skills you developed this year are yours forever.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child present artwork with articulate explanations, perform music with confidence and technique, manage a multi-part public event, and demonstrate pride in creative accomplishments?
slides.mascot_explanation: Think about all the wonderful things you did today – you made art, you learned music, and you shared it all with the people who care about you. That takes a lot of bravery and hard work, and you should feel so proud of yourself for being so creative and dedicated. These skills will help you no matter what you do when you grow up!

parent_notes: The combined art show and concert is the creative culmination of the year. Treat it as a real event: dress up a little, dim lights for atmosphere, serve refreshments, and give the child your full, enthusiastic attention. Sign the guest book with a meaningful comment. Take plenty of photos and video. If other family members or friends can attend, the larger audience amplifies the experience enormously. After the event, talk about specific moments: a particular artwork that impressed you, a song that sounded beautiful, the moment they seemed most confident. This experience builds the foundation for a lifetime of creative expression and performance confidence. For summer, provide art supplies and encourage free creative expression. Visit museums, attend concerts, and expose the child to diverse forms of artistic expression.
